lessons.title: Introduction to Systems of Equations

standard_details.description: Given a system of two linear equations and a possible solution, determine whether the possible solution is an actual solution.

objectives: Define a system of linear equations
Identify ordered pairs as potential solutions
Verify solutions by substitution into both equations
examples: Check if (2, 3) is a solution to x + y = 5 and 2x - y = 1
Verify if (1, 4) solves y = 3x + 1 and x + y = 5
Determine if (0, 0) is a solution to 2x + 3y = 0 and x - y = 0
common_misconceptions: Only checking one equation instead of both
Assuming close values mean the solution works
real_world_applications: Checking if a business plan meets both revenue and cost requirements
Verifying if a recipe maintains both taste and nutrition goals

lessons.title: Testing Multiple Solutions

standard_details.description: Given a system of two linear equations and a possible solution, determine whether the possible solution is an actual solution.

objectives: Explain why a point is or isn't a solution
examples: Test (1, 1), (2, 2), and (3, 3) for x + y = 4 and 2x - y = 2
Find which of three given points solves a system
Explain why (5, 0) doesn't work for a given system
common_misconceptions: Stopping after finding one equation that works
real_world_applications: Quality control: checking if products meet multiple specifications
Navigation: verifying coordinates satisfy multiple constraints

lessons.title: Understanding Types of Systems

standard_details.description: Given a system of two linear equations represented graphically on the same coordinate plane, determine whether there is one solution, no solution or infinitely many solutions.

examples: Determine solutions from graphs of intersecting lines
Identify no solution from parallel lines graph
Recognize infinite solutions from overlapping lines
common_misconceptions: Missing that overlapping lines have infinite solutions
real_world_applications: Understanding when two businesses compete for the same market
Analyzing when supply and demand curves meet

lessons.title: Analyzing Graphed Systems

standard_details.description: Given a system of two linear equations represented graphically on the same coordinate plane, determine whether there is one solution, no solution or infinitely many solutions.

examples: Read intersection point from a graph grid
Identify parallel lines by equal slopes
Recognize same line by matching all points
common_misconceptions: Not extending lines far enough to see intersection
real_world_applications: GPS navigation finding intersection of two roads
Architecture determining where beams cross

lessons.title: Graphing Systems - Part 1

standard_details.description: Given a mathematical or real-world context, graph the solution set to a system of two linear equations in two variables.

objectives: Graph two linear equations on the same coordinate plane
Use slope-intercept form to graph efficiently
examples: Graph y = 2x + 1 and y = -x + 4 on the same plane
Graph x + y = 5 and 2x - y = 1 by converting to slope-intercept form
Set up a coordinate plane for a system
common_misconceptions: Not using a ruler for straight lines
real_world_applications: Mapping two different hiking trails
Comparing two linear growth patterns

lessons.title: Graphing Systems - Part 2

standard_details.description: Given a mathematical or real-world context, graph the solution set to a system of two linear equations in two variables.

objectives: Identify the intersection point from a graph
examples: Find where y = x + 2 and y = -x + 6 intersect
Graph and solve: 2x + y = 8 and x - y = 1
Verify a graphical solution by substitution
common_misconceptions: Graphing inaccurately and getting wrong intersection
real_world_applications: Finding when two phone plans cost the same
Determining when two investments have equal value

lessons.title: Graphing Systems - Special Cases

standard_details.description: Given a mathematical or real-world context, graph the solution set to a system of two linear equations in two variables.

examples: Graph y = 2x + 1 and y = 2x - 3 (no solution)
Graph y = x + 2 and 2y = 2x + 4 (infinite solutions)
Identify special cases algebraically
common_misconceptions: Graphing parallel lines with slight intersection
real_world_applications: Understanding when two rules are contradictory
Recognizing when two descriptions are identical

lessons.title: Systems Review and Assessment

standard_details.description: Apply previous knowledge of operations to solve a system of two linear equations.

examples: Mixed practice with all three standards
Real-world system problems
Error analysis on system solutions
real_world_applications: Budget planning with multiple constraints
Travel planning with time and distance requirements

lessons.title: What is a Function?

standard_details.description: Given a set of ordered pairs, a table, a graph or mapping diagram, determine whether the relationship is a function. Identify the domain and range of the relation.

objectives: Define function using the vertical line test
Understand that each input has exactly one output
Identify relations that are and aren't functions
examples: Determine if {(1,2), (2,3), (3,4)} is a function
Check if {(1,2), (1,3), (2,4)} is a function (not a function)
Use vertical line test on various graphs
common_misconceptions: Thinking a function can't have same y-values
Confusing x and y in function notation
real_world_applications: Temperature as a function of time
Cost as a function of quantity purchased

lessons.title: Domain and Range

standard_details.description: Given a set of ordered pairs, a table, a graph or mapping diagram, determine whether the relationship is a function. Identify the domain and range of the relation.

objectives: Define domain as the set of all input values
Define range as the set of all output values
Identify domain and range from various representations
examples: Find domain and range of {(1,3), (2,5), (4,7)}
Determine domain and range from a graph
Identify domain and range from a table
common_misconceptions: Missing values when reading from graphs
real_world_applications: Possible inputs and outputs for a vending machine
Valid ages and heights for a growth chart

lessons.title: Functions from Tables and Mapping Diagrams

standard_details.description: Given a set of ordered pairs, a table, a graph or mapping diagram, determine whether the relationship is a function. Identify the domain and range of the relation.

objectives: Find domain and range from multiple representations
examples: Analyze a mapping diagram for function property
Check if a table represents a function
Convert between ordered pairs, tables, and mapping diagrams
common_misconceptions: Thinking mapping diagrams must be one-to-one
Not checking all entries in a table
real_world_applications: Student ID to student name mapping
Product code to price relationships

lessons.title: Functions from Graphs

standard_details.description: Given a set of ordered pairs, a table, a graph or mapping diagram, determine whether the relationship is a function. Identify the domain and range of the relation.

objectives: Apply vertical line test to graphs
Read domain and range from continuous graphs
Distinguish function graphs from non-function graphs
examples: Test various graphs with vertical lines
Find domain and range of a parabola
Identify domain and range of a discrete function
common_misconceptions: Applying horizontal line test instead of vertical
Not extending domain/range to all visible values
real_world_applications: Analyzing stock price graphs over time
Reading elevation profiles on hiking maps

lessons.title: Introduction to Linear Functions

standard_details.description: Determine whether a relation represented in tabular, graphical or algebraic form is a linear function.

examples: Identify if y = 2x + 3 is linear
Check if y = xÂ² is linear (not linear)
Recognize y = 5 as a linear function
real_world_applications: Constant speed travel distance
Hourly wage calculations

lessons.title: Linear Functions from Tables

standard_details.description: Determine whether a relation represented in tabular, graphical or algebraic form is a linear function.

objectives: Check for constant differences in tables
Calculate rate of change from table values
key_concepts: Constant change in y per unit change in x
examples: Find if a table shows constant rate of change
Calculate slope from a table
Identify nonlinear pattern in a table
real_world_applications: Analyzing linear growth in savings
Checking for constant speed in distance tables

lessons.title: Linear Functions from Graphs and Equations

standard_details.description: Determine whether a relation represented in tabular, graphical or algebraic form is a linear function.

objectives: Identify linear functions from straight-line graphs
Recognize linear equations in various forms
examples: Identify if 3x + 2y = 6 is linear
Check if y = 1/x is linear (not linear)
Recognize graphs of linear vs nonlinear functions
real_world_applications: Uniform pricing models
Constant rate conversions

lessons.title: Increasing and Decreasing Functions

standard_details.description: Analyze a real-world written description or graphical representation of a functional relationship between two quantities and identify where the function is increasing, decreasing or constant.

objectives: Define increasing, decreasing, and constant intervals
Use interval notation to describe behavior
key_concepts: Increasing function (y increases as x increases)
Decreasing function (y decreases as x increases)
Constant function (y stays same as x increases)
examples: Identify where a graph is increasing
Find constant intervals on a graph
Describe all behaviors of a piecewise graph
real_world_applications: Stock price trends over time
Temperature changes throughout a day

lessons.title: Analyzing Real-World Function Graphs

standard_details.description: Analyze a real-world written description or graphical representation of a functional relationship between two quantities and identify where the function is increasing, decreasing or constant.

objectives: Connect graph features to real situations
examples: Analyze a water tank filling/draining graph
Interpret a driving trip distance vs time graph
Describe temperature changes shown on a graph
common_misconceptions: Not connecting graph shape to situation
real_world_applications: Analyzing business revenue over time
Understanding population growth patterns

lessons.title: Function Behavior from Descriptions

standard_details.description: Analyze a real-world written description or graphical representation of a functional relationship between two quantities and identify where the function is increasing, decreasing or constant.

objectives: Identify function behavior from verbal descriptions
examples: Graph a story about a car trip
Match function descriptions to graph shapes
Identify increasing/decreasing from a written scenario
common_misconceptions: Drawing literal pictures instead of graphs
Confusing time sequence with graph position
real_world_applications: Describing business trends in words
Explaining scientific observations

lessons.title: Functions Unit Review

standard_details.description: Define, evaluate and compare functions.

objectives: Determine if relations are linear functions
key_concepts: Integration of function identification and analysis
examples: Mixed practice with all three standards
Real-world function problems
Multiple representation problems
real_world_applications: Complete analysis of real-world functional relationships

lessons.title: Introduction to Scatter Plots

standard_details.description: Construct a scatter plot or a line graph as appropriate for the context.

objectives: Define scatter plot and its purpose
Plot ordered pairs on a coordinate plane
examples: Create scatter plot of height vs shoe size
Plot temperature vs ice cream sales data
Choose appropriate scale for large data values
real_world_applications: Analyzing relationship between study time and test scores
Comparing age to reaction time

lessons.title: Creating Line Graphs

standard_details.description: Construct a scatter plot or a line graph as appropriate for the context.

objectives: Define line graph and when to use it
Plot and connect data points chronologically
Choose between scatter plot and line graph
examples: Create line graph of temperature over 24 hours
Graph population growth over years
Decide whether to use scatter plot or line graph
common_misconceptions: Using line graphs for unrelated data points
real_world_applications: Tracking stock prices over time
Monitoring patient vital signs

lessons.title: Describing Patterns in Data

standard_details.description: Given a scatter plot or line graph within a real-world context, describe patterns showing the relationship between two quantities.

objectives: Identify positive, negative, and no correlation
examples: Describe pattern in height vs arm span scatter plot
Identify negative correlation in altitude vs temperature
Recognize no correlation in shoe size vs test scores
real_world_applications: Understanding advertising spend vs sales relationship
Analyzing practice time vs performance
